docs.title: Project Overview
docs.text:
TaskVault is a secure, role-based task management backend system built using Django REST Framework. It is designed to support both individual task management and team-oriented workflows with strong access control and auditability.

The system enables users to create and manage their own tasks, while administrators can assign tasks, monitor progress, and review task activity across the system. Every meaningful change to a task is recorded, ensuring transparency and traceability.

TaskVault is API-first and can be integrated with any frontend application such as React, Vue, Flutter, or mobile clients.

docs.title: Problem Statement
docs.text:
Many task management systems fail to clearly separate responsibilities between regular users and administrators. They often lack strict access control, reliable task history, and structured handling of task ownership and assignment.

TaskVault addresses these issues by providing:

  • Clear separation between user-owned and admin-assigned tasks
  • Structured priority and status tracking
  • Secure, role-based access control
  • Immutable audit history for task changes
  • Soft deletion to preserve data integrity

docs.title: Proposed Solution
docs.text:
TaskVault provides a structured backend solution with:

  • Role-based access control (Admin and User)
  • JWT-based authentication
  • Clear task ownership and assignment rules
  • Status and priority management for tasks
  • Immutable task history for auditing
  • Comment-based collaboration on tasks
  • Soft delete strategy across all major entities

This approach results in a secure, scalable, and auditable task management system suitable for team and enterprise use.

docs.title: System Architecture
docs.text:
TaskVault follows a layered backend architecture that separates responsibilities clearly and keeps business logic maintainable.

Request Flow:

Client → URL Router → DRF Views → Serializers → Service Layer → Models → PostgreSQL Database

docs.title: Architectural Principles
docs.text:
• API-first design
  • Separation of concerns
  • Explicit permission handling
  • Service-based business logic
  • Soft delete over hard delete
  • Immutable audit logs

docs.title: Modules Breakdown
docs.text: Module Description users Authentication, user management, roles tasks Task CRUD, assignment rules, filtering comments Task discussion and collaboration task history Immutable audit logs for task updates core Shared utilities, permissions, pagination

docs.title: Authentication & Roles
docs.text: TaskVault uses JWT (JSON Web Token) based authentication. All protected endpoints require a valid access token.

docs.title: Authentication Mechanism
docs.text:
• Access Token: Used for authenticated API requests
  • Refresh Token: Used to obtain a new access token
  • Tokens are issued during login
  • Tokens are invalidated on logout
  • Deleted users cannot authenticate

docs.title: Roles
docs.text:
TaskVault defines two roles:

  • Admin
  • User

Each role has clearly defined capabilities.

docs.title: Role Capabilities
docs.text: Capability Admin User Register account Yes Yes Create task for self Yes Yes Assign tasks to users Yes No View all tasks Yes No View assigned tasks Yes Yes Update self tasks Yes Yes Update assigned tasks Yes Yes Delete self tasks Yes Yes Modify task history No No

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
TaskVault is designed as a secure, scalable, and role-based task management backend system. It addresses common limitations of traditional task tracking applications by enforcing strict access control, maintaining immutable audit logs, and ensuring data integrity through soft deletion.

TaskVault’s API-first design allows it to be easily integrated with modern web and mobile frontends. Its structured workflow, combined with task history and comments, makes it suitable for both individual task management and team-based collaboration environments.

docs.title: Future Scope
docs.text:
TaskVault is designed with extensibility in mind. Possible future enhancements include:

  • User reactivation and restore workflows for previously soft-deleted users.
  • Task restoration and archival features for long-term task storage.
  • email verification for user register
  • Notification and alert systems for task assignments, updates, and deadlines.
  • Role expansion to support additional user types such as managers or reviewers.

docs.title: Permissions Flow
docs.text: TaskVault uses explicit permission classes to control access. All permission logic is centralized in core/permissions.py.

docs.title: Permission Strategy
docs.text:
• Authentication is enforced globally
  • Object-level permissions are used for sensitive resources
  • Views do not contain role or permission logic
  • Permissions are evaluated against actual model instances

docs.title: Permission Examples
docs.text:
• Admin can access all tasks
  • User can access only assigned or self-owned tasks
  • Comments inherit permissions from their parent task
  • Task history is visible only if task access is allowed

docs.title: Benefits
docs.text:
• No permission duplication
  • Clear enforcement rules
  • Easy to test and extend
  • Consistent behavior across the system

docs.title: System Requirements
docs.text: This section outlines the functional and non-functional requirements of the TaskVault system.

docs.title: User Management
docs.text:
• The system shall allow users to register and authenticate using JWT.
  • The system shall support two roles: Admin and User.
  • Users shall be able to update their own profile information.
  • Administrators shall be able to view, update, and soft delete any user.
  • Users shall be able to soft delete their own account.
  • Soft deletion of a user shall cascade to tasks and comments owned or assigned to the user.

docs.title: Task Management
docs.text:
• Users shall be able to create tasks only for themselves.
  • Administrators shall be able to create tasks for themselves or assign tasks to users.
  • Each task shall include title, description, status, priority, and optional deadline.
  • Duplicate task titles for the same owner–assignee combination shall be prevented.
  • Users shall be able to view only tasks assigned to them or created by them.
  • Administrators shall be able to view all tasks.
  • Tasks shall support filtering by owner, assignee, status, and priority.
  • Tasks shall be soft deleted instead of permanently removed.

docs.title: Task Updates and History
docs.text:
• Task status, priority, and deadline shall be updatable.
  • Deadlines shall not be allowed in the past.
  • The system shall record immutable history entries for task status or priority changes.
  • Task history shall remain accessible even if the modifying user is deleted.

docs.title: Comments
docs.text:
• Users shall be able to comment on tasks they own or are assigned to.
  • Administrators shall be able to comment only on tasks they own.
  • Users shall be able to update and delete their own comments.
  • Comments shall be soft deleted.

docs.title: Access Control
docs.text:
• Role-based and object-level permissions shall be enforced for all protected endpoints.
  • Deleted users shall not be allowed to authenticate or access APIs.

docs.title: Security
docs.text:
• All protected APIs shall require authentication.
  • Passwords shall be securely hashed.
  • JWT shall be used for stateless authentication.
  • Soft-deleted users shall be blocked from system access.

docs.title: Performance
docs.text:
• Pagination shall be enabled for all list endpoints.
  • Indexed fields shall be used for frequently queried columns.
  • UUIDs shall be used for primary keys.

docs.title: Reliability and Maintainability
docs.text:
• Soft deletion shall be used to prevent accidental data loss.
  • Audit logs shall be immutable.
  • Permission logic shall be centralized and reusable.
  • APIs shall follow consistent response structures.

docs.title: Usability and Portability
docs.text:
• APIs shall follow RESTful design principles.
  • PATCH shall be used for partial updates.

docs.title: Task History System
docs.text: TaskVault maintains an immutable audit log for task updates.

docs.title: What Is Recorded
docs.text:
• Old and new task status
  • Old and new task priority
  • User who made the change
  • Timestamp of change

docs.title: Design Principles
docs.text:
• History records are never updated or deleted
  • History is created only when meaningful changes occur
  • History is read-only via API

docs.title: Access Rules
docs.text:
• Admin can view history of any task
  • User can view history only for tasks assigned to them
